identificationModule.briefTitle: ESWT for Shoulder Pain in Patients With Brain Damage
identificationModule.officialTitle: The Effects of Extracorporeal Shockwave Therapy (ESWT) for Shoulder Pain in Patients With Brain Damage

descriptionModule.briefSummary: This study aimed to investigate the efficacy and safety of extracorporeal shockwave therapy (ESWT) for upper extremity pain related to spasticity in patients with spinal cord injury.
descriptionModule.detailedDescription: 6 times of ESWT (3,000 pulses per time, low energy under 0.3 mJ/mm\^2, tolerable range) on subscapularis and lesser and greater tuberlces of humerus to reduce pain in patients with brain damage

armGroups.label: Experimental group
armGroups.description: 3,000 pulses per time, low energy under 0.3 mJ/mm\^2, tolerable range

interventions.name: Extracorporeal shockwave therapy
interventions.description: Extracorporeal shockwave therapy 6 times during 2 weeks

primaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Up to 4 weeks (baseline, after each treatment during 2 weeks, 2 weeks + 1 day, 4 weeks)

secondaryOutcomes.description: Scoring scale consist of 5 pain scale and 8 disability scale, in %, 0 (best) to 100 (worst)
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Up to 4 weeks (baseline, 2 weeks + 1 day, 4 weeks)

eligibilityModule.eligibilityCriteria:
Inclusion Criteria:

* Brain damaged patient confirmed in the brain image
* 1 month after brain damage
* Pain in hemiplegic shoulder areas more than 4 points on the numerical scale (NRS)
* Cognitive functions that can clearly point out NRS with more than 15 points in the mini mental state examination (MMSE)
* Age: 20 and older
* Person who has agreed in writing to decide his or her participation and comply with the precautions

Exclusion Criteria:

* Pain due to trauma
* Injection treatments two weeks before participating in the study
* Severe coagulopathy (excluding antiplatelet use)
* Impaired cognition

overallOfficials.name: MinYoung Kim, MD, PhD
overallOfficials.affiliation: Department of Rehabilitation Medicine, CHA Bundang Medical Center, CHA University School of Medicine

locations.facility: Department of Rehabilitation Medicine, CHA Bundang Medical Center
